I've put more than sixty hours into this game and Contagion's gameplay design is fundamentally broken. I want it to be good, but it's not. This breaks my heart because I know that a team spent many many manhours trying to make this into a cool game. I really wish it was a proper successor to ZPS.   Coming from around a thousand hours in ZPS, I was attracted to Contagion's 'Escape' mode and I played this mode the most. There are other modes, but they are generally bland copycat 'afterthoughts' that are done better in other games. Escape is the only mode that enticed me to get Contagion.   However, Escape has numerous fundamental game design flaws that permanently gimp its gameplay. To illustrate, it's best to walk through a typical Escape game:      'Escape' generally begins as a co-op mode with up to around 8 teammates. Initially, you're playing against only NPC zombies. However, the NPC zombies are completely boring to fight against. You either have boring citizen zombies that die to a single headshot or you have uninspiring bullet-sponge riot-armor zombies. I couldn't find any engaging strategy to defeat these bullet-sponges except repeated shots to the noggin. Therefore, the NPC zombies are more of a chore to fight through.      Even though players soon find that the NPC zombies don't post much threat, the level design, itself, will kill them (either literally or figuratively):       There are simple 'no no' level design decisions like the the frequent use of ladders. Since Contagion is built on Source, ladders are horrific and will literally get players killed without any zombie involvement ( Even Valve wisely prefers to not use ladders in Source ). When I completed Camp Whitner for the first time, I was led through by an experienced player (see showstoppingly confusing level design below) and he literally stops at one point to say, 'Watch out, this ladder will kill you.' I knew how Source ladders worked and carefully navigated down the shaft. My other inexperienced teammate did not and was instakilled by fall damage. The experienced player obviously knew about the trouble from that stupidly unnecessary ladder. I'm not sure how the developers could have so much experience with Source dating back to ZPS in 2007 and still not know that ladders are terrible level design.      There are also situations where the macro-scale level design pathing is so bad on certain maps that new players will just quit out of frustration. Maps like Barlow Square on Escape prematurely appear like easy-to-navigate 'sandbox' urban 'city' maps (awesome! right?). So at first you might go, 'oh cool, that gun shop is a couple blocks west of our position. Let's make our way in that direction!' However, you have ZERO navigational liberty and you are FORCED onto a 100% LINEAR path due to miles of chainlink fence that procedurally block every path except ONE. This might only be 'bad', but it moves to 'terrible' when you find out that the dynamic path is often obscurred and basically hidden. If you are a new player that isn't aware that there's exactly one path to move through the map, then you will quickly get confused, then frustrated, then you'll quit. This happens on a painfully regular basis. The zombies don't end their fun - it's the map's level design that does that.      Furthermore, there are  micro-scale  level design issues. The latest example is one that I just experienced this morning.  I was trying to beat Montclair with some equally inexperienced players and we got to a military medical base in a park. After easily clearing it of boring NPC zombies, we walked past a locked gate and we were told to go find the key in the park. We didn't know what this 'key' looked like, but we combed the park nevertheless. We came up with nothing, yet we kept looking for what felt like hours. It got so desparate that the player-controlled zombie started trying to help us find it. Eventually my only living partner turned into a zombie as a result of a random bite and I just quit to end that pitiful match. This is one example of how needlessly frustrating this game is. Stuff like this is simply unfun.        But if you manage to get through all of those inherent level design flaws, then you'll notice that player-controlled zombies are frighteningly unbalanced. It gets so bad, that some experienced players intentionally die at the beginning of the match just so they can single-handedly destroy their former teammates before they can even get through the first couple objectives. How in the world can it be so unbalanced?      It's almost impossible to hit a player zombie as compared to an identical NPC zombie. I've heard players claim that player zombies have unique hitboxes. My hunch is that the game has poor networking and it's normally masked by allowing NPC zombie hits to be credited only clientside (versus player zombie hits that must be validated serverside). Either way, this is a very very very noticeable phenomena and it makes player zombies very difficult to deal with.      Oh and player zombies can 'dodge' as well. The experienced ones know that if their head stays unscathed, then they can tear through a group of players, so they spin, duck, jump and do all sorts of stupid moves to turn themselves into a walking killing machine. That's not fun. This is not a featured capability. There's no tooltips or tutorials that explain all of the intricacies of this maneuvering. That tells me that it isn't a designed feature. And since it ruins entire Escape servers, I say it's an exploit that is unpatched two years after release.       I really drive home hard enough that this is a frustrating game to play. If I hadn't dropped a thousand hours in ZPS, I would've abandoned it long ago. This game does not play like ZPS. It's something much much worse and that breaks my heart.

There's clearly money and effort put into everything in this to try to elevate it above being a source mod, but none of that matters if the core gameplay is bad. Popping zombies in the head with your pistol is fun for a while, and tense as it's not easy but I am being serious when I say there is nothing else there to the gameplay.  Guns are scarce to a point where you more luck into a playstyle than you do choose how you want to play or adapt to what's going on. However, ammo is plentiful and melee weapons are so dangerous and inconsistent they are useless.  There's a barricade tool, but it's only useable for certain areas and useless the rest of the time.  There's cool ideas, but none of them are implemented well. Not one.   I have played an ♥♥♥-ton of zombie games looking for good ones and I want this one to be good. But jesus christ the devs have been asses on the forums, the game has only gotten limited support since release and it doesn't look like it will be turning around any time soon.  Go play Zombie Panic: Source or No More Room in Hell. Both are better and free.  Somehow No More Room in Hell comes out feeling more polished, despite this having a budget.   If you really want to defend this game, you can talk to me in the commments, but jesus christ I have no idea how you sado-masochists do it.  It's not that fun, it's not scary and it's not scary enough to justify the core gameplay not being fun.

+ Impressive visuals; exterior environments look incredible; water/rain effects really stand out and react wonderfully with lighting + Cell phone is a great feature that was integrated very well with gameplay + Only a handful of game-modes, but many of them are novel and fun with tons of replay value + Controlling zombies after death was very well implemented; devs put more thought into this than most games of the genre, and there is an unexpected amount of functionality + Maps are surprisingly large and easy to lose yourself in + Barricading mechanics are simple and intuitive + Game engine is very, very well-optimized; the game runs smoothly + Maps change every game; Objectives differ, paths close and open, item/weapon pickups are randomized + Voice communications operate on differing channels; survivors use one channel, and player-controlled zombies use another (this adds so much to the game, as player controlled zombies can effectively coordinate against their former companions, basically turning death into the start of a new game with new objectives, on the same map, against other players - VERY fun) + None of those endlessly recycled 'special' zombies that are so prevalent in other games of the genre (with the exception of a 'riot-gear' zombie, but they are just scarce enough to be a minor challenge without the pitfalls of being irritating)  - Melee weapons were not as well done as I've seen in other products of this genre, and they are rarely used; the game places an overwhelming emphasis on firearms   If you enjoyed this review, please follow my  curator page . Also, feel free to join my group,  LockeProposal's Big Day Out  for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

I don't recommend the game, not because it's 'bad', but because it's mediocre. There's nothing really special about this game to recommend it to anyone. I got it on sale, and it's given me about 20 hours of moderate fun, so I'd say I'm satisfied. Don't pay any more than $5 for this.  Pros: - It's fun to shoot zombies - The Sig Sauer is really fun - The flashlight looks great - Boarding up a house and then shooting zombies through doors is really cool - Big levels  Cons: - Zombies are only really affected by headshots. Contagion prides itself on being more realistic, but a .45 ACP to the chest will slow anything down - as it is, anything other than a headshot is wasted ammunition. - Guns sound bland, except for the Sig Sauer. I really wish game developers would take field trips to gun ranges to hear what guns actually sound like, rather than just relying on movies. - Too much bullet spread. If guns were as inaccurate as they are in this game, nobody would use them. I pointed a rifle at a wall about 20 meters away, didn't move the mouse, and fired five times, waiting enough time in between each shot for the rifle to settle down again. I checked the wall and there were five different bulletholes. At 20 meters, you should be able to put a round in the same place all day long. - It isn't cognitively demanding at all. If you try to take it slow and be smart, you'll be disappointed, as every encounter ends up being a non-stop headshot fest.  Overall, I think they could've done better. It feels like it's in Early Access, or something that might have once appeared on XBox Live Arcade. Underwhelming stuff.

At first this game seem to be a worthy investment. It throw out of the window the arcade, repetitive and boring gameplay that standardized L4D; focusing on speed runs from point 'A' to 'B' slicing and gunning through hordes of zombies and 'specials', just to arrive to a 'safe house' full of weapons and ammo, and repeat the same thing two or three more times in order to finish a map.  Contagion focus it self on cooperative gameplay, management of resources (weapons and ammo), map exploration in order to find those resources and find a one of the three randomly generated scape routes. The gameplay is a 'relistic' survival zombie game, were only head shots kills zombies, attacks from them cause infection and ammo is littely found. The problem is, the game has bugs since it early access like zombie pathfinding, charcters skeletons, animations..., there is no lobby and kick system, to play multiplayer with your friends only you must have your own server, there is only a few maps to play and to make it worst there is no modding community fix that. There characters are lifeless and boring, they only swear bad words and that's it. L4D is FAR MUCH BETTER in that aspect and also in the maps. Contagion has good mechanics, but L4D has better characters, better maps and better modding support. A great zombie game would be the mix of these two games OR a remastered first person edition of Resident Evil Outbreak.

I have found this game incredibly fun and fulfilling, even with the more limited content available. The slightly slower pacing compared to a run-n-gun zombie shoot-em-up is refreshing as you have to actually scavenge for your ammo and supplies and, especially on harder modes, conserve as much as you can.  If you like cooperative play like I do, the escape and extraction modes are fun, especially if you find a good group of people. In escape, you have to navigate a level with some objectives and obstacles that rotate through a couple different scenarios, and in extraction you locate NPC survivors, hold out for a time against hordes, and then escort them to a drop off point. As with any online game, you will probably get in several games with people that aren't as cooperative or skilled, but when you have a good team it's very fun.  If you favor competitive play, there's always hunted and panic modes. Hunted is your basic pvp, where players killed become zombies and when there's two left, all NPC zombies charge at the two remaining players. In Panic, one player begins the game infected but may not know it for a few minutes, and the only zombies in the level are the player zombies, while the first player zombie respawns as a SWAT zombie. Human players have to kill the zombies a certain number of times, or survive for like 20-30 minutes to win. All in all, I got the game on sale for $5, and I would say it's the best 5 I've spent in a long time. Yes, some graphics aren't as up-to-date and some animations can be wonky, but it's not distracting to me at all. I would recommend this game even at the 20 price if you think this sort of thing appeals to you.

Really good game for those of you who like zombies.  Great Survivor vs Survivor action, aswell as several Co-op modes vs both AI and Player Zombies.  Hunted - S vs S based mode with Player Zombies aswell. You spawn in a random location on the map, and your objective is to stay alive the longest. Scavenge the abandoned houses along the way, but beware - hitting B as a human brings up your phone, and you and other players can see who is close aswell as get a buzzing noise when hitting the trigger. If you die you will respawn as a zombie and your only task is to bring down the remaining survivors. Last survivor alive wins the round.  Escape - Band together with friends and strangers in this Survivor vs AI / PC zombies. Your phone will let you know what objective you need to accomplish and your main goal is to escape from the map. Weapons, ammo and items will be found along the way. Make sure you check every corner as they are sometimes hidden or you need to progress further to unlock the areas they are in.  Extraction - Survivor vs AI / PC zombies where your goal is to follow the GPS on your map and find survivors held up in houses. Once you reach a holdout point, vast amounts of zombies will begin spawning, so share your ammo and your weapons with your friends, as each member of your team that gets killed will come back as one of the ravenous corpses coming to eat you. Round ends when all survivor packs have been extracted, or the zombies kill either all Player survivors or NPC survivors in a pack.  Panic (Objective) - The P:O mode was taken from the spiritual prequel Zombie Panic! Source, another game worth picking up as it's free, and features a strictly PS vs PZ combat zone, where the survivors need to complete the objectives much like in Escape.  Panic (Classic) The original game mode from ZP!S which just like the Objective mode features only player combat. Survive the zombie rush. Zombies have limited lives and the first player to turn becomes the strong Riot Zombie.  Happy hunting and good luck surviving!

The main game mode is called escape and sees up to 8 players try to work their way through a map full of zombies to escape a situation. The puzzles are pretty basic and usually involve finding an item to open a door or barrier. Each time you play the game the route changes, keys change location, different doors are unlockable/open, one game saw the team using vents to get around the map instead of taking the stairs. The zombies are easy enough to kill but a lack of ammo and limit to the number of things you can hold means that you often resort to using risky melee weapons. The limits on holding 5 things at once mean that through the game you do things such as swap a key for machine gun with no ammo(in the hope you will find ammo) only to find that the armory later in the game is locked..   Deathmatch sees up to 8 players battling it out on medium sized maps filled with zombies. While not strong the zombies are a great addition to the fight. The match is slow paced and it can be quite hard to find other human players, following a hoard who can smell human blood is a great way to track people down. Other ways to find humans include following flashlights, which works great when you see a small flash in the front room of the house next door or following gunshots. Gunshots is a great idea by the developers because at some point human players find themselves cornered in a loft with a zombie they need to take out; unfortunately, unless you have 5.1 sound its unlikely to help locate people that much.   I should point out the game is beta, so there is plenty of time for things to change. I don’t know how being a zombie can be more fun while not making them too powerful for humans. While it takes a while to hunt a human player down in escape mode, this stops the humans getting overran by 5 zombie players. I should also note that while being a zombie was a tad boring, playing as a human was really fun. It was also really tense, death actually meant something to the player and kept you on your toes.  I’m giving this 4.5 stars because I’m knowingly taking part in a beta. Perhaps I would give it 3.5 if this was the finished product, but it’s not. Reviewing games at this stage in their life is perhaps a little unfair, but I think its good giving games trying something new and following the kickstarter/green light/beta business models as much coverage as possible.   4.5/5 stars :D

There are currently three game modes, one in which you must escape a facility carrying on a number of tasks, another where you need to evacuate a neighbourhood before it gets overwhelmed (and you must hold position barricading and such) and a game called 'hunt' made for PVP combat. Although there are few maps at the time, you can see they are very detailed and won't get bored so easily as there is also a script which randomizes each game making it feel fresh, changing everything from weapon spawns to open hallways and houses.  All in all and even though it's early access this game is a gem and if you're into zombie shooters you should give it a test drive because it may be just what you were looking for.

3.5/5 game I figured I would give this game a chance since it was up for free for the weekend. Now, I'm a big fan of killing zombies, I rarely get tired of putting a shot or a axe in the skull of a zombie. With this in mind, I like what Contagion is, but there are things about it I'm not too crazy about it. Before I go about posting what I think is great about the game, I will start with the things I'm not too crazy about.  1. Forgettable characters - Aside from picking the character you like, that is really about all there is to character selection. There just isn't anything that makes you remember the character beyond it's appearance.  2. Lack of a story - Now I know the game isn't a RPG or anything, but a little bit of story would be nice. Matter of fact it would be a nice way for the character's to be rememberable.  3. Flashlight needs work - Now the flashlight is very handy and by no means am I saying it's useless. However, why can the flashlight not light up rooms? It just seems to light up a small area and jeebus don't get too close to anything in particular with it. The light at the center can just about block out the view of items. You cannot even light up a room for a fellow survivor whose weapon doesn't allow a flashlight fitting.  4. Lack of Zombie variations - Aside from the standard Zombie, player Zombie, and Riot armored zombie. There really isn't anything else of danger around. A Zombie dog would have been a great addition to this game, or even enviromental hazards like falling buildings, out of control cars crashing, or something. A well organized team can easily put down a army of zombies, unless of course they're out of ammo.  5. Ammo hoarders - Don't get me wrong, when you need ammo badly, you need it badly. However, there are people that will pick up ammo for every gun BUT the gun they actually have. I cannot tell you how many times I've been down to one bullet and cannot even get a person to throw a magazine or ammo box my way.  6. Terrible Iron Sights - Now you don't need to serve a tour of duty in a war to tell some of these weapons have terrible iron sights. I've had times where I've woundered if it was easier to shoot from the hip or just aim down sights. Obviously it's better to aim down the sights, but some weapons just have such terrible iron sights it renders players ineffective at times. However, if you get use to the iron sights, you can easily work your way around their terrible design. Out of all the guns, your best bets are on the Pistols, the shotgun, and the hunting rifle. Pistols are semi-automatic, so you can control your rate of fire with them. Shotgun has bad iron sights, but it makes up for it with a wide shot spread so you just need to aim for the head. Heck you may even take down more than one zombie with a single shell. The Hunting rifle zooms in and it's the sniper rifle, so you don't have to deal with iron sights with it.  7. Getting stuck on stuff - This is more of a minor complaint, but there are times that it feels like I get stuck in doorways at times. It looks like I got enough room to enter, but some how I still get stuck.  Now for the things I like about the game.  1. The Enviroment - It actually feels like a proper zombie apocalypse. Nothing is clean, nothing is overly destroyed. Things feel just right.  2. Zombies are true to nature - Short of shooting them in the head, blowing them up with a grenade, or hitting them with a melee weapon. A zombie will keep coming after you. Thank you devs, these are true Zombies!  3. Sound effects - The sound effects in this game are really good in my opinion. Since there is no real map to use, you can listen for the gun shots of your fellow survivors to actually tell you a general idea of what direction they're at. Or as a Zombie you can use it to find where your targets are at (short of using the vision sight for foot prints.) Overall everything sounds good in this game.  4. Limited resources - Nothing worse than playing a survival game and finding every little thing you need in the world in no time. Ammo, weapons, and medical kits are so hard to find. You actually have to concern yourself on how you approach the streets, corners, buildings, and rooms.  5. Infection - There is a chance when you get hit by a zombie that you actually get infected. If you're infected, there is a limit of time before you start to feel it and eventually turn against your fellow survivors. You won't know you're infected till it's too late. Some people may find this annoying, but I love it. Even if you die as a survivor, the game isn't over for you. Because now you can fight against them as a zombie and lead Hordes of zombies towards them. (Nice way of getting payback on those Ammo hoaders)  6. Board up and hold out - Now I know everyone likes base building, but honestly it get's old seeing player made sky forts or whatever. Contagion may not have base building, but boarding up windows is one of the most logical ways of keeping the zombies out. I just wish the boards didn't fall inbetween line of sights. If a Zombie gets close enough to try and break into the building, it's hard to get them off the window boards without shooting the defense itself.  7. Plenty of maps and game modes - The game isn't limited to just your typical 'Start at A and get to C by moving through B' (Though ti does have a escape mode which is fun still), but you also have a PVP game mode where players start off killing each other, then holding out against zombie palyers in a game of Hide and seek. A objective based game where players locate survivors and take them to be extracted across zombie infested streets or neighborhoods. Also with players seemingly able to make their own playable maps, it's no real concern about there ever really being a feeling of a lack of enviroments to play in.  8. Maps change - Nothing better than playing a map that can change from another playthrough. I've had games where doors that were usually unlocked, were actually blocked off. So really you cannot predict what route you must take to get to a objective, you sort of have to learn on the fly.  9. Random starting gear - Our survivors may be all different, but the nice thing is that they start out with random gear. You may have just a pistol at first one game, then the next you may have a pistol and a SMG. I just feel this is a nice way to keep things feeling interesting.  Overall Contagion isn't a bad game, but it doesn't do too many things great. With some stuff fixed, a few improvements made, and some other little things. The game can honestly stand toe to toe with the Left 4 Dead games. Don't take this as me saying 'i want it to be more like Left 4 Dead.' I just want to see some more stuff that will pull me into the game more. One more zombie type, fixed weapon iron sights (or at least a visual zoom in), and some other little things would just be perfect for someone like me. While I cannot stand playing the game for hours on end. I can at least say what time I do play, I enjoy greatly.  If you see this game on sale and you want a good little Zombie shooter game, I would highly suggest picking this game up. I only paid five bucks and don't regret it.

Contagion is a 2011 medical thriller directed by Steven Soderbergh. The film features an ensemble cast that includes Marion Cotillard, Bryan Cranston, Matt Damon, Laurence Fishburne, Jude Law, Gwyneth Paltrow, Kate Winslet, and Jennifer Ehle. Contagion's plot documents the spread of a virus transmitted by fomites, attempts by medical researchers and public health officials to identify and contain the disease, the loss of social order in a pandemic, and finally the introduction of a vaccine to halt its spread. To follow several interacting plot lines, the film makes use of the multi-narrative 'hyperlink cinema' style, popularized in several of Soderbergh's films.  Soderbergh and screenwriter Scott Z. Burns had collaborated on The Informant! (2009). Following that film's release, both considered creating a biopic covering Leni Riefenstahl's life, before Burns brought up the idea of producing a medical thriller film depicting the rapid spread of a virus, which was inspired by various pandemics such as the 2003 SARS epidemic and the 2009 flu pandemic. To devise an accurate perception of a pandemic event, Burns consulted with representatives of the World Health Organization as well as noted medical experts such as W. Ian Lipkin and Lawrence 'Larry' Brilliant. Principal photography started in Hong Kong in September 2010, and continued in Chicago, Atlanta, London, Geneva, and San Francisco until February 2011.  Contagion premiered at the 68th Venice Film Festival in Venice, Italy on September 3, 2011, and went on general release on September 9. The film was well received by critics, who praised the narratives and the performances of various actors and actresses. It was also well received by scientists, who praised its accuracy. Commercially, the film was a moderate box office success. Budgeted at USD $60 million, Contagion attained $135 million in box office revenue during its theatrical run.

You're trying to walk forward but you cannot because the invisible borders of a table or such is blocking you. Move a tiny bit to the side and you can walk forward. Shooting stuff.. just eww. Firstly Contagion uses the (now) standard ADS for aiming and shooting. But how it actually feels and behaves as you play will drive you insane. It is the most frustrating thing ever when you are aiming at the head of a zombie around a car length away, fire and you miss. Zombie is only slightly wobbling from side to side, not moving and you miss. You aim a second time, ever carefully aiming and aligning the sights, fire and miss a second time. At this point you cuss, throw the mouse across the room, smack ESC and promptly exit the game. It is really hard to put into words how frustrating and annoying the aiming and shooting is in this game but maybe just saying it does not feel 'natural' or comfortable would suffice. Anyone who has ever shot a handgun or a rifle in real life can relate to the next issue. When the game is trolling you with stuff like 'There is no automatic reload' and then you shoulder an AR-15.. facepalm immediately. Feels like you're trying to shoulder it but at the same time you move your head as back as possible while pushing the rifle as far as possible from you and then you're trying to squint through the sights. I cannot understand how they could mess up so badly the main idea of ANY zombie shooter, the actual shooting. Some other things to note (in bad or good, you decide). There are only two zombie types, regular and 'riot', where the latter is 'armored' (Yes a riot helmet and vest will totally resists several rounds of intermediate cartridges or higher). The maps are quite nice and realistic looking. Realistic in the sense of how one would imagine it to be in this type of situation. Graphics look quite outdated (In my opinion Left 4 Dead looks much better, yes the first). Game modes are pretty 'standard' with the usual PvE (escape and civilian rescue)/PvP and mixed modes of those two.  The few hours that I've played Contagion I really do not recommend it. The idea and premise seem promising but the execution and playability is horrible that it will frustrate you to no end. For the money there are better alternatives.

If you've played Left 4 Dead, it's basically more of the same but with less special infected (there's only the bullet-sponge that is the riot-gear zombie) and more objectives.  There are also different gamemodes available. Things like Escape, where you try to do exactly that, while completing objectives along the way (unlock this, go here, press this, hold off against these, etc), Evac, where you go around collecting survivors to escort to safety, or the true PvP gamemode where you hunt each other when you're alive and have to watch out for zombies.  If a player dies, they come back as a zombie. This will usually ruin the game if you're in a small team, because for some reason they take a lot more damage. They also bob and weave which, combined with their pings, means you miss a lot before they're tearing at your face. But in a large group, it's usually not a problem.  But I mostly enjoy the Escape maps. Completing objectives as they appear on the phone you use to tell you were to go has a satisfying sense of accomplishment. While you're killing zombies, you're keeping an eye out for things like key cards, boltcutters, or keys, just in case they're useful later. It brings a sense of teamwork, when each person gives up a valuable weapon slot to carry an item that we might need later. And it all comes together when you've fought through hell, got down to your last clip, and then you find a locked door that you can open with something you've saved that whole time. All the goodies waiting behind, ready to re-kit your team into killing machines.  All in all, a game I enjoy wasting a couple of hours on here and there, though I would advise to wait for it to go on sale (the full price is a bit steep, in my eyes).  Edit: I would like to mention this: if you become a zombie, you only get 4 lives and then you enter spectator mode for the rest of the game. A terrible idea, really, and I hope it gets changed.

Pros: (From a survivor point of view. I haven't played as a zombie enough to make a judgemental call on the mechanics.)  - A fresh take in a market saturated with zombie game clones. I would put it's character towards a more fast-paced No More Room In Hell. - There is attention to detail. The developers are stubborn, but they're putting in work that counts. - A fun, team-based game where team work is almost necessary in PVP modes such as Extraction (with player zombies). Working together gives you a real sense of accomplishment - The movement of your player, aiming/shooting, and the pathing involved in maps is fluid and crisp. - Weapons (guns) look and feel the way they should. - It's the zombie apocalypse in it's raw form; Zombies, and that's it. - Official servers can USUALLY handle the amount of bandwidth a full game demands. - Multiple game modes to choose from, as well as various maps (both night and day) that can give you replayability beyond what you'd expect. - The community is USUALLY friendly, meaning that your team mates and enemies are usually friendly folks. There's always a few bad eggs in every basket, so I can't knock it for that. It's Steam, expect it everywhere. - Extraction-based objectives vary each time you play, so you get a different path each time you play a certain map. That adds replayability as well.  Cons:  - When servers DO spiral out of control from the use of bandwidth in a full game, it really drags you down. A few laggy players that are connecting from a far enough distance (120 ms+) will affect everyone. Once the game starts getting bogged down, a lot of finesse and quick reactions absolutely required to emerge victrorious in any PVP game start to become impossible to execute. Bullet lag and frame skipping (not graphical) will get you killed before you know it.  - Melee weapons are a bit pointless at times. The ammo the game gives you, even in the most extreme difficulties, is usually over the top and enough to supply four players.  - When you DO use melee weapons, they all feel exactly the same and make no sense. The Kabar knife has close to the same range as, say, the fireaxe or the sledgehammer.  - Regardless of range, melee weapons never have a greater length of attack than the zombies. You have to close in so much to a target that even if they're standing still, you have the risk of getting hit by a zombie whilst slinging your sledgehammer around. That's a big issue for me.  - Knockback. I know it sounds cliche, but I expect at least a little reaction from a zombie when they get pegged in the head from the head of a sledge at full swing. They don't. They don't even skip a beat. Nothing. And when you're moving around a lot while a zombie is attacking you, that lack of reaction is cringe-worthy and will most likely end up with you being hit. I'm not the best at this game, but I have my feet firmly planted on the ground.  - Player zombies, novice or seasoned veteran, love to approach you the same way every time. You bee-line your way to the player and crouch, jump, make unpredictable/unrealistic movements and spam left click from a range that exceeds that of AI zombies. The player zombie may appear ten feet away from you, but he can sure as hell hit you. This makes melee even more pointless against player zombies. Latency/Lag only amplifies these dimensions, making any game that isn't 40 or less ms a frustrating struggle. The PZs, as they're called, should be more of a glass cannon type. They have infinite respawns, and do so instantly when they're killed. No downtime. Therefore, I think they should have a higher rate of damage, but less mobility and range.  - Another issue with latency is dealing with hitting a PZ. I've seen myself and others shoot a Remington 870 police magnum at point blank range with several shots at one. Regardless that we've seen both visual and audio confirmation that the PZ had been hit in the head (blood splatters and squishy flesh sounds), they simply don't take any damage. When a PZ is heading towards you in aforementioned bee-line, it only makes it more nonsensical and proves my point.  - Voice acting is sub-par, but comical at best. There's an option to turn it off all together, and I would highly recommend so. It gets a tad annoying when your character is yelling the same cliche lines literally every 10-15 seconds.  Overall, this game has enough to offer that I'd say give it a shot! It's not the greatest, but it's most definitely not the worst. I'm interested to see where the developers take this game in the near future.

Nobody bats an eye over the extreme oversaturation of MilSims or Super Man Shooters.  Moving on, this game does well BECAUSE its on the good old Source Engine. The graphics are amazing for such an old engine, and because its on source, it generally means everyone can play it, even low end PCs. Its also different than a lot of zombie shoot-em-ups in the sense that you have to be slow and deliberate, you cant zoom through everything with an asinie amount of ammunition and the stamina (and strength) of a bull on Special K. Its like Insurgency with zombies. In other zombie shooters you want to have all the zombies come to you so you can chop them up one by one or mow them down with a SAW, but in Contagion, you want to stay as low on the zombies radar as you can. One gunshot in the wrong place at the wrong time can really ♥♥♥♥ you. Thats another reason this game is disliked so much, because its so hard, and I wont lie, its hard. If you dont like difficult games, stay clear of this one. Other than that, great game, great engine, solid gameplay.
